hypotheses: Education and individual time preferences affect asymptomatic disease detection and management, but their effects differ for individuals in good general health versus poor general health.

For individuals in good general health, education may not increase the probability of being diagnosed (and could have smaller, zero, or even negative effects) because higher education raises opportunity costs of undergoing routine exams.

For individuals in poor general health, education increases the probability of being diagnosed because poor health lowers current earning potential and the opportunity-cost channel and awareness channel reinforce each other.

Time preferences (impatience) increase the probability of being under-diagnosed for individuals in good general health (they forgo routine physicals), but time preferences matter less (or not significantly) for individuals in poor general health.

Similar differential effects of education and time preferences will be observed for disease management once patients are diagnosed (education and patience promote better management, with heterogeneous magnitudes by general health status).
claim.hypotheses_location: Introduction (end of Section 1) and Theoretical framework (Section 2), pages 15-17 of the paper (statements of hypotheses and reduced-form equations).
claim.statement: Education and individual time preferences affect asymptomatic disease detection and management, with effects differing between individuals in good general health versus poor general health.
claim.statement_location: Abstract and Introduction (Abstract on page 15; reiterated in Introduction and Conclusions, pages 15 and 21).

data.source: Indonesian Family Life Survey (IFLS), fourth wave (IFLS4)
data.wave_or_subset: Fourth wave of IFLS, fielded November 2007 to April 2008; sample restricted to hypertensive adults (age over 45 in 2007) and subsamples by self-reported general health status
data.sample_size: 4209 hypertensive adults for disease detection analyses; 1696 previously diagnosed hypertensive respondents for disease management analyses (3145 in good general health subsample and 1064 in poor general health subsample for detection; 1100 good / 596 poor for management).
data.access_details: The IFLS is described as a publicly available data set (IFLS4 fielded by RAND in collaboration with Indonesian institutions); IRB approval noted. No specific download link or repository provided in the paper.
data.notes: Blood pressure measured three times by trained nurses; first measurement dropped and average of the last two used to construct hypertension. Hypertension defined per WHO (systolic >140 or diastolic >90). Under-diagnosed defined as hypertensive by IFLS measurement but not previously diagnosed by a doctor. Time and risk preferences elicited via sequences of hypothetical lottery questions; respondents grouped into four categories for time and risk preferences following Ng (2013). Per-capita expenditures (PCE) used as proxy for income. Potential endogeneity of education and time preferences acknowledged by authors. No raw dataset link or codebase provided in the paper.

method.description: Using IFLS4 survey data, the authors identify hypertensive individuals via measured blood pressure and compare those previously diagnosed by a doctor versus those undiagnosed. They estimate probit models (reporting marginal effects) for (a) probability of being under-diagnosed conditional on being hypertensive, and (b) probability of engaging in recent blood pressure monitoring (disease management) among previously diagnosed patients. Key covariates include years of education, elicited time and risk preference groupings, log household per-capita expenditures (PCE), distance to nearest health center, age and age-squared, and sex. Analyses are conducted for the aggregate sample and separately for respondents reporting good versus poor general health.
steps: Use IFLS4 data (fielded Nov 2007–Apr 2008) and select respondents aged over 45 who are hypertensive based on measured blood pressure (average of 2nd and 3rd measurements; hypertensive if systolic >140 or diastolic >90).
Construct under-diagnosed dummy: 1 if hypertensive per IFLS measurement and respondent reports never having been diagnosed previously by a doctor.

Elicit and classify individual time and risk preferences from IFLS hypothetical lottery questions, grouping respondents into four categories (from most patient to most impatient / least risk averse to most risk averse) following Ng (2013).
Construct other covariates: years of formal education, log household PCE, distance to health center, age and age-squared, sex.
Split sample by self-reported general health status (GHS): 'good' (very/somewhat healthy) vs 'poor' (somewhat/unhealthy).
Estimate probit models for the probability of being under-diagnosed on aggregate and separately for GHS subsamples; report marginal effects and standard errors.

For disease management, restrict to previously diagnosed hypertensive respondents and construct a management dummy equal to 1 if respondent checked blood pressure at least once in the month preceding interview; estimate analogous probit models and report marginal effects.
Interpret coefficients and marginal effects, focusing on heterogeneity across GHS subsamples; perform multicollinearity checks (Belsley et al. referenced).
method.models: Probit regression models with marginal effects reported (reduced-form regressions for probability of being under-diagnosed and probability of recent blood pressure monitoring).
method.outcome_variable: Primary: binary indicator of being under-diagnosed (hypertensive by measurement but not previously diagnosed). Secondary (disease management): binary indicator of checking blood pressure at least once in the month prior to interview (restricted to previously diagnosed hypertensives).
method.independent_variables: Years of education (formal schooling), time preference grouping (elicited, four categories), risk preference grouping (elicited, four categories), log household per-capita expenditures (PCE), distance to health center, age and age-squared, sex (female dummy).
method.control_variables: Age and age squared included in all regressions; sex, log PCE, distance to health center, risk preference included as additional covariates.

results.summary: At the aggregate level, years of education, individual time preferences (impatience), household economic resources (log PCE), distance to health center, and sex are associated with probability of hypertension under-diagnosis. However, effects differ by general health status: for respondents in good general health, education is not a significant predictor of under-diagnosis whereas time preference and access (distance) matter; for respondents in poor general health, education has a larger and significant positive association with being diagnosed (i.e., reduces under-diagnosis) while time preference and distance are not significant. For disease management (recent blood pressure monitoring among previously diagnosed), education positively predicts monitoring for all respondents with larger effects for those in poor general health; time preference matters for the aggregate sample and for respondents in good health but not for those in poor health. Overall, a large share of hypertensive individuals are under-diagnosed (~59.7%), and among previously diagnosed only ~23.9% had checked blood pressure in the prior month.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Under-diagnosed (aggregate sample) - marginal effect of years of education
numerical_results.direction: positive (additional year of education associated with small decrease in probability of being under-diagnosed; reported as significant at 10% level in table)

numerical_results.outcome_name: Under-diagnosed (respondents in good health) - marginal effect of years of education
Under-diagnosed (respondents in poor health) - marginal effect of years of education
Under-diagnosed (aggregate sample) - marginal effect of time preference
numerical_results.direction: positive (more impatient associated with higher probability of being under-diagnosed; significant at 1% level)

numerical_results.outcome_name: Disease management (aggregate sample) - marginal effect of years of education
numerical_results.direction: positive (each additional year of education associated with higher probability of recent blood pressure monitoring; significant at 1% level)

numerical_results.outcome_name: Disease management (respondents in poor health) - marginal effect of years of education
numerical_results.direction: positive (larger positive effect among those in poor general health; significant at 1% level)

metadata.original_paper_title: Education, individual time preferences, and asymptomatic disease detection
